text: {| |} Brunswick was launched at Hull in 1829 as an East Indiaman. She sailed to India several times under a license from the British East India Company, but was wrecked in 1832. ==Career== Brunswick entered Lloyd's Register in 1829 with Rosendale, master, changing to A. Parker, E. Gibson, owner, and trade Hull–Calcutta.Lloyd's Register (1829), Supple. pages "B", Seq.№B20. Brunswick, A. Parker, master, sailed to Madras and Bombay on 21 April 1829.Register of Shipping (1830), "Licensed ships to India – 1829". On 2 December 1831 Brunswick,, J. Palmer, master, sailed to Bengal.Lloyd's Register (1833), "Ships trading to India -1831". ==Fate== Brunswick, Blewett, master, wrecked on 11 October 1832 in the River Hooghly. She was returning to London from Calcutta. She wrecked on Sagar Island, India with the loss of a crew member. She was on a voyage from Bengal, India to London. ==Citations and references== Citations References * *Selection of Reports and Papers of the House of Commons: Commerce and manufactures and admeasurement of shipping, (1836), Vol. 22. title: Brunswick (1829 ship)
